title: How to Dry Coconut

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (177 degrees C).
Drill the coconut through the eyes using a 3/8 inch (9.5 mm) drill bit.
steps.description: Pour the coconut water into a dish or cup. The water should be clear. Cloudy or colored water means the coconut is bad. You can discard the water or drink it if desired.

steps.headline: Put the coconut directly on the rack in the preheated oven.
Remove the coconut from the oven and wrap it in a towel, creating a sack.
steps.description: Hold the end of the towel to keep the coconut stable and hit the coconut several times with a hammer to break it up.

steps.headline: Pry the flesh out of the coconut with a strong knife, such as a paring knife.
steps.description: The flesh may have a thin brown skin attached from where it was touching the shell. Remove the skin with a vegetable peeler.

steps.headline: Reduce the oven temperature to 250 degrees F (121 degrees C).
Shred the coconut pieces in a food processor and spread them onto a cookie sheet.
steps.description: Dry the coconut in the oven for 10 to 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Let cool and transfer the dried coconut to an airtight container.
steps.description: Store the coconut in a cool, dry place.

steps.headline: Bust up the coconut with a hammer.
Peel the innards out of the coconut.
Use a cheese grater to grate the flesh.
steps.description: use the coarse side of the grater.

steps.headline: If you want the dried coconut to be a little sweet, put some sugar on it (1 - 2 teaspoons).
Dehydrate for about 8 hours at 135 degrees F.
Bag the dried coconut.
steps.description: Use an airtight container or an airtight resealable bag.

text: Oven drying Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (177 degrees C).  Drill the coconut through the eyes using a 3/8 inch (9.5 mm) drill bit. Pour the coconut water into a dish or cup. The water should be clear. Cloudy or colored water means the coconut is bad. You can discard the water or drink it if desired. Put the coconut directly on the rack in the preheated oven. Heat the coconut for 20 minutes. Remove the coconut from the oven and wrap it in a towel, creating a sack. Hold the end of the towel to keep the coconut stable and hit the coconut several times with a hammer to break it up. Pry the flesh out of the coconut with a strong knife, such as a paring knife. The flesh may have a thin brown skin attached from where it was touching the shell. Remove the skin with a vegetable peeler. Reduce the oven temperature to 250 degrees F (121 degrees C).  Shred the coconut pieces in a food processor and spread them onto a cookie sheet. Dry the coconut in the oven for 10 to 15 minutes. Let cool and transfer the dried coconut to an airtight container. Store the coconut in a cool, dry place. Dehydrating Bust up the coconut with a hammer.  Peel the innards out of the coconut.  Use a cheese grater to grate the flesh. use the coarse side of the grater. If you want the dried coconut to be a little sweet, put some sugar on it (1 - 2 teaspoons).  Dehydrate for about 8 hours at 135 degrees F.  Bag the dried coconut. Use an airtight container or an airtight resealable bag.
sentences: Oven drying Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (177 degrees C).
Drill the coconut through the eyes using a 3/8 inch (9.5 mm) drill bit.
Pour the coconut water into a dish or cup.
The water should be clear.
Cloudy or colored water means the coconut is bad.
You can discard the water or drink it if desired.
Put the coconut directly on the rack in the preheated oven.
Heat the coconut for 20 minutes.
Remove the coconut from the oven and wrap it in a towel, creating a sack.
Hold the end of the towel to keep the coconut stable and hit the coconut several times with a hammer to break it up.
Pry the flesh out of the coconut with a strong knife, such as a paring knife.
The flesh may have a thin brown skin attached from where it was touching the shell.
Remove the skin with a vegetable peeler.
Reduce the oven temperature to 250 degrees F (121 degrees C).
Shred the coconut pieces in a food processor and spread them onto a cookie sheet.
Dry the coconut in the oven for 10 to 15 minutes.
Let cool and transfer the dried coconut to an airtight container.
Store the coconut in a cool, dry place.
Dehydrating Bust up the coconut with a hammer.
Peel the innards out of the coconut.
Use a cheese grater to grate the flesh.
use the coarse side of the grater.
If you want the dried coconut to be a little sweet, put some sugar on it (1 - 2 teaspoons).
Dehydrate for about 8 hours at 135 degrees F.  Bag the dried coconut.
Use an airtight container or an airtight resealable bag.
